awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Kinetic-based self-transitioning turbulence modeling for pulsatile flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Pulsatile flows are omnipresent in nature and engineering systems. Understanding turbulence in pulsatile flows is critically important to both knowledge advancement and technological innovation. However, challenges have remained due to the lack of appropriate turbulence computational models that solve the inherent unsteadiness with successive transitions from laminar to turbulent, and then back to laminar flow during pulsation. The prevailing flow criteria of either laminar, or transitional, or turbulent flow developed from stationary pipe flows are not appropriate for pulsatile flows; the existing turbulence models based on Kolmogorov theory for fully-developed turbulence are not suitable, either. With the support of laboratory experiment, this project is to establish a new self-transitioning turbulence modeling method for time-wise pulsatile flows. An important impact of this research will be on the precision medicine of image-based patient-specific noninvasive diagnose and assessment of cardiovascular diseases. The project will provide various opportunities for multidisciplinary training for graduate/undergraduate students, as well as for curriculum development at both Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis and City College of New York. 

The goal of this project is to develop and validate a new kinetic-based self-transitional turbulence model for solving the laminar-turbulent-laminar transition in pulsatile flows, in which the need of modeling for small scale motion is automatically activated/deactivated when the spatial or temporal resolution is insufficient/sufficient to resolve the entire range of scales when flow is accelerating/decelerating in a pulsation. Explicit filtering is applied to resolved-scale solutions in transitional flows to adapt the sub-grid scale model to dynamic temporal and spatial resolution requirements. The sub-grid scale model is embedded in the kinetic-based lattice Boltzmann method to achieve disruptively fast computation speed through massive parallelization on graphic processing units. In-depth understanding of turbulence in pulsatile flows under various influences of inertia and viscous effects, pulsating frequency, geometric curvature and bifurcations will be explored through concurrent numerical simulation and laboratory experiment.  General criteria of laminar, transitional, and turbulent behaviors in unsteady pulsatile flows will be unveiled, which are critically important to software-based computational fluid dynamics for pulsatile flows where, conventionally, laminar or turbulent flow must be predefined before the simulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Solving the fluid dynamics of pulsatile flows plays an important role to enable knowledge advancement and technological innovation in life sciences, material sciences, energy, and engineering. Pulsatile flows are inherently unsteady with successive flow acceleration and deceleration. The prevailing flow criteria of either laminar, transitional, or turbulent flow developed from stationary pipe flow are not appropriate for pulsatile flows; the existing turbulence models based on Kolmogorov theory for fully developed turbulence are not suitable for pulsatile flows, either. This project addressed two important aspects: the advancement of turbulence modeling, including direct numerical simulation (DNS) and large-eddy simulation (LES), for pulsatile flows in very complicated (arbitrary) flow domains, and the underlying physics of laminar to turbulent flow( turbulentization) and then back to laminar flow (relaminarization) in pulsation.

This project has resulted in new turbulence modeling methods, DNS and LES, for solving unsteady pulsatile turbulence in image-based flow domains. We used the volumetric lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) to solve the pulsatile fluid dynamics. We introduced a volumetric parameter defined as the occupation of solid volume in a lattice cell, enabling a self-regularized collision, streaming, and fluid migration for a moving boundary in VLBM. We creatively used unified LBM modeling for image segmentation and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) on a graphic processing unit (GPU) platform, resulting in a seamless connection of both and exceptionally fast computation. The DNS code was extensively validated using analytical solutions, experimental measurements, and medical data. It can accurately solve pulsatile pipe flows with Re numbers up to 5000 without computation burdens. The typical computation time for 10 cycles of blood flow in a diseased human arterial system anatomically extracted from Computed Tomography Angiography images is around 20 minutes, exceptionally faster compared with the hours and days usually spent. We derived the first-ever 3-D kinetic-based discrete dynamic system (DDS) from the lattice Boltzmann equations via a separation of large-scale and sub-grid scale (SGS) motions. The DDS involves five bifurcation parameters with specific physical meanings. We perform numerical experiments for the DDS in terms of time series and power spectra and demonstrated its capability to capture laminar and turbulent behaviors. We systematically studied the effects of the bifurcation parameters on the DDS performance using deep-learning techniques and identified the optimal bifurcation parameters that achieve the best performance. We then embedded the DDS into the DNS code to activate the SGS modeling when the spatial or temporal resolution is insufficient to solve the entire motion scales in a pulsation. This new LES modeling is featured with physical accuracy and computational simplicity and efficiency.

We systematically studied the instability and turbulentization in pulsatile pipe flows. The Reynolds (Re) numbers ranged from 535 to 4825 and Womersley (Wo) numbers from 6.3 to 23.82. We have found that the transition to turbulence is a spontaneous event covering the whole near-wall region. At the low frequency of pulsation, the transition is delayed to higher Re numbers, where the appearance of turbulence is not modulated anymore by the frequency of pulsation. Inflectional instability of the velocity profile leads to flow separation and the formation of a major roll-up structure with the K-H vortices superimposed. At higher Re numbers, the strength and extent of the vortices are larger and substantial disturbances appear in the free stream region of the flow which is typical of pipe flows at transitional Re numbers. Turbulence appears to be produced at the locations of maximum or minimum vorticity within the attached wall vortical layer. A transition can take place at much lower than Re = 2200 because of flow reversals.

To date, the project has produced nine journal or Juried conference papers (six published and three under review), four thesis/dissertations (three graduated and one graduating), and 15 conference presentations. Five manuscripts are in preparation for journal publication. The research topics were involved in the semester projects of three graduate courses. About 15 undergraduate students via IUPUI Multidisciplinary Undergraduate Research Institute were trained in image processing, postprocessing, and data analysis. The project was exposed to K-12 students. Nontechnical talks were presented in three summer camps via Minority Engineering Advancement Program (MEAP), Preparing Outstanding Women for Engineering Roles and Information Technology (POWER+IT), and NSF ITEST (Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers) project, with 55 high school students in the grades of 9-12, involving minorities and women students.

The project has resulted in two GPU-accelerated computational platforms that impact diverse applications. One enables fast quantification of pulsatile hemodynamics in diseased human arteries based on medical images. Such a capability will lead to new noninvasive and personalized hemodynamic indices to assess the true hemodynamic severity of vascular diseases and proper revascularization.  Another enables solving pore-scale flows in image-based porous media. Two US national labs have started to use the computational platform to stimulate particulate flows and nuclear waste flows in polymer materials.
